titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Violet Trefusis Papers
titlestmt.author: by Kathryn Rawdon

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 03:09
profiledesc.descrules: translation missing: en.enumerations.resource_finding_aid_description_rules.beinecke manuscript unit archival processing manual

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Collection contains correspondence, writings and other materials by or related to Violet Trefusis. The correspondence consists chiefly of approximately 500 letters from Trefusis to John Phillips written in the 1960's. Also included are letters to Trefusis from her mother, Alice Keppel, her sister, Sonia Keppel, and her husband, Denys Trefusis; several governmental departments in France and England concerning Trefusis's re-entry into France after World War II; and her nomination to the Légion d'honneur. Writings include holograph and typescript drafts of Trefusis' memoirs, novels, plays and other writings. Other materials include a photograph of Denys Trefusis; a miniature case portrait of Trefusis as a child; and an album containing photographs of friends of the Keppels, taken by George Keppel between 1924-1939 at the family's Villa dell'Ombrellino in Florence, including many members of European nobility and royalty.

langmaterial.language: Chiefly in English, some materials in French.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Maggs Brothers Ltd. and Bertram Rota Ltd. on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund and Starling W. Childs Library Fund, 1994, 1996, and 2003.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Violet Trefusis Papers are the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Violet Trefusis Papers. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

Restricted Fragile materials in box 6 and in the portfolio may only be consulted with permission of the appropriate curator. Preservation photocopies or photographic prints for reference use have been substituted in the main files.

bioghist.head: VIOLET TREFUSIS, 1894-1972
bioghist.p: Violet Keppel was born in London on June 6, 1894. When Violet was a child, her mother, Alice Keppel, became the mistress of the Prince of Wales (later King Edward VII), until his death in 1910.

In 1904, Violet began an enduring friendship with Vita Sackville-West. The relationship developed into a difficult and tumultuous love affair that lasted from approximately 1918 to 1921, and which for a time alienated Violet from her mother and from society. It also caused problems with her husband, Major Denys Trefusis, whom she had married in 1919. They eventually reconciled publicly, if not privately, and moved to Paris in autumn of 1921. Denys Trefusis died of tuberculosis in 1929, the same year Violet published her first book, Sortie de secours .

In 1927, Violet purchased a medieval ruin in Saint-Loup-de-Naud, outside of Paris. The complex became her home until 1940, when she was forced to flee to England the escape the German invasion. She spent the war years in England, resuming her friendship with Vita Sackville-West, and publishing several more works, including her novelized version of her affair with Vita, Broderie anglaise . She also broadcast for the Free French on the BBC. After the war, she returned to France. In 1950 she was awarded rank of Chevalier of the Légion d'honneur for her wartime broadcasts. She published her autobiography, Don't Look Round , in 1952. Alice Keppel died in 1947, leaving her daughter Violet as the proprietor of L'Ombrellino, the Florentine villa the Keppels had purchased in the 1920's. Violet Trefusis died in Florence on February 29, 1972.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four series: I. Correspondence, 1939-1971. II. Writings, 1940-1956. III. Additional Materials, 1924-1939. IV. January 2003 Acquisition, 1919-1955.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Violet Trefusis Papers document the life of Violet Trefusis, particularly her later life of the 1940's-1960's, and her career as a writer. The Papers consist of correspondence, writings, photographs, and a miniature portrait of Trefusis. The material spans the years 1924-1971, and has been organized into four series: Correspondence , Writings , Additional Materials , and January 2003 Acquisition . The January 2003 Acquisition has not been merged with the rest of the collection and is listed separately.

Series I, Correspondence (1939-1956)
, contains letters to and from Violet Trefusis. The majority of the correspondence consists of 72 letters to John Phillips, whom Trefusis met in 1960. In them she discusses her life in Florence, Paris and Saint-Loup-de-Naud, her travels around Europe, her health, and her many friends and acquaintances. With these letters is a spiral-bound photocopy of typescripts of many of the letters, including explanatory footnotes by Phillips. The letters to Trefusis include letters from Alice Keppel, detailing Keppel's life during and after World War II, and mentioning money concerns, family matters and acquaintances. There are also several letters from Trefusis' sister, Sonia Keppel (Mrs. Ronald Cubitt), primarily discussing their mother and the sale of their mother's possessions after her death. Also included are letters from the French and British governments regarding Trefusis' return to France after the war, and her nomination to the Légion d'honneur, as well as one letter from Harold Nicolson, husband of Vita Sackville-West. Other correspondence includes letters from Alice Keppel to her husband George Keppel discussing Sonia (whom she calls "Doey") and Violet (called "Bye"), one letter from Frank Ashton-Gwatkin and one from Alice Segodnia, both to John Phillips.

Series II, Writings (1940-1956)
, contains holographs and typescripts of novels, memoirs, plays, short stories and other writings by Trefusis, including several of her broadcasts for the BBC, and descriptions of people she knew, including Colette, the Sitwells, and Louise de Vilmorin.

Series III, Additional Materials (1924-1939)
, contains a large photograph album with approximately 600 photographs taken in the 1920s and 1930s, primarily by Violet's father, George Keppel, at the Keppels' Villa dell'Ombrellino in Florence. The album contains photographs of many members of the aristocracy, nobility and literary elite of the day, including Lady Clementine Churchill, Antoinette, duchesse d'Harcourt, Raymond Mortimer, Winaretta, princesse de Polignac, Sir George Reresby Sitwell, and Osbert Sitwell. A list of names of individuals appearing in the album is available in the Appendix. A full listing of the contents of the album, including a description of each photograph, is included in the box with the album. Also included in this series is a miniature oval portrait of Trefusis as a child.

The January 2013 Acquisition contains letters written to Violet Trefusis, a photograph of Denys Trefusis, third party correspondence, and two lists of books kept by Violet's friend Gilone (Princesse de) Chimay during the war, with Violet's autograph notes.

odd.head: Appendix: Contents of Photograph Album (in Series III)
odd.p: This album contains approximately 600 black and white photographs, many with partial or full captions. Below are names which appear as captions in the album, in the fullest possible form. Names which appear in quotes are transcribed exactly as they appear in the album. A more detailed listing of each photograph is included in the box with the album.
Esher, Oliver Sylvain Baliol Brett, Vicount Esher

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

The bulk of the collection was processed in 1998. The January 2003 Acquisition received a basic level of processing in 2015, including rehousing and minimal organization. This acquisition has not been merged with the remainder of the collection. Instead, it is described separately in the contents list below, identified by a unique call number and titled according to month and year of acquisition.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.
This collection includes materials previously identified by the call numbers Uncat MSS 460 and Uncat MS Vault 328.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Former call numbers: Uncat MSS 460 and Uncat MS Vault 328

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The January 2003 Acquisition primarily contains letters written to Violet Trefusis, including a letter from Denys Trefusis with a photograph of him enclosed. All letters are to Violet Trefusis unless otherwise indicated. Some third party correspondence is also included, as are two lists of books kept by Violet's friend Gilone (Princesse de) Chimay during the war, with Violet's autograph notes. Most of the material included in this acquisition is in French.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Bertram Rota Ltd. on the Starling W. Childs Library Fund, 2003.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter from Denys Trefusis regarding their impending marriage, with a photograph of Denys
Permission for Violet to travel to England to flee German invaders
Autograph letter, signed, from "Jean" regarding war conditions

Autograph letter from an unidentified sender regarding a sea voyage in West Africa and residents of the region
Autograph letter from an unidentified sender
Autograph letter from an unidentified sender
Three autograph letters from "P.H." regarding social matters
Typed letter, signed, to Cyril Connolly from Peter De Mendelssohn stating that the story by Violet Trefusis in the June issue of Horizon magazine is a "little masterpiece"
Two lists, one manuscript and one typed, of books kept by Violet's friend Gilone (Princesse de) Chimay during the war, with autograph notes by Violet
Typed letter to "Madame Ia Duchesse" concerning a cache of silver owned by Violet that had been hidden from the Germans during the war by the Duchesse D'Harcourt
Typed letter, signed, from "Sylvia" from the Beekman Tower, New York City with manuscript corrections and notes, including a quotation from Sappho
Four autograph letters, signed, from Violet's suitor, Marchese Guido Sommi Picenardi
Autograph letter, signed, from Dorothy Heneage, expressing sadness due to Violet's mother's approaching death
Autograph letter, signed, from 'Tony" (Done Antonio De Gandarillas) concerning Violet's mother's death
Eleven autograph and typed letters, signed, from Betty Batten concerning social matters, mutual friends, including Nancy Mitford, and Violet's character
Autograph letter, signed, from Frank Ashton-Gwatkin, from the Royal Institute of International Affairs, London
